position.marginalia_text: Prudens non est, qui sibi ipsi est imprudens.
Poco fa, chi à se non gioua.

marginalia.translation: He who is imprudent with himself is not prudent. He who is not useful to himself accomplishes little.

position.marginalia_text: Sera nimis Vita est Crastina: viue hodie. Sufficit diei sua malitia: inquit ipse Christus. Sua militia: ait Ca[e]sar. Hodiè mihi: cras tibi. In Experientia, finis conspicitur eorum, in quibus aliquis est excellentior. Inter pueros puer: inter viros vir: inter senes senex: qualem partem vnamquamq[ue] habemus mortale genus. Percurrit autem et quatuor Virtutes mortale a[e]vum. Cogitare autem decet de eo, quod propè est. Pindarus Ode 3. Nemeorum. Qui vincit, reliqua in vita habet mellitam tranquillitatem, propter pra[e]mia victoria[e]. Semper autem quod vno quolibet die obuenit bonu[m], summu[m] venit omni mortali. Idem Ode I. Olymp. Luctus opprimitur grauis à potiorib[us] bonis. Ode 2. Ex fluctibus semper is, qui circa pedem nauis voluitur, dicitur cui libet maximè perturbare animu[m]. Ode 6. Nemeorum.

emphasis.text: Cogitare autem decet de eo, quod propè est
Sera quod vno quolibet die obuenit bonu[m], summu[m] venit omni Vita

marginalia.translation:
"Tomorrow is too late for life: live today. Christ himself says, "Sufficent for each day is its own trouble." Caesar says, "Its own warfare." Today is mine, tomorrow is yours.
By trial the accomplishment is made manifest, of that in which a man proves himself preeminent, as a boy among young boys, a man among men, or, thirdly, among elders, according to each stage which we, the race of men, possess. And mortal life sets in motion four excellences, and bids us to think of what is at hand. Pindar's Third Nemean Ode.
A victor throughout the rest of his life enjoys honeyed calm, so far as contests can bestow it. But at any given time the glory of the present day is the highest one that comes to every mortal man. The same, First Olympian Ode.
Their heavy sorrow collapsed in the presence of greater blessings. Second Olympian Ode.
But the wave that rolls nearest to the ship is said to stir the spirit most of all. Sixth Nemean Ode." [Trans. Diane Arnson Svarllien]

position.marginalia_text: Valdè sapit, qui Sibi ipsi nunq[uam] repugnat in Medijs, ad suum Finem: sed semper Causas applicat, suo Effectui accommodatas. Memor Scopi.

marginalia.translation: He who never contradicts himself in the middle of things until he reaches the end knows much. But he always turns his mind to opportunities suitable for his accomplishment. Mindful of the goal.

position.marginalia_text: Oculus semper in vexillo. Ad scopum, vnaqua[e]q[ue] pharetra[e] sagitta. Ad vnu[m], eundemq[ue]. Scopum ta[e]la singula.

marginalia.translation: Always keep your eye on the prize. Towards the goal, each and every arrow of the quiver. Towards on and the same thing. Singular spears of the goal.
